Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\) where \\( i \\) is the imaginary unit and \\( x(t) \\), \\( y(t) \\) are real-valued functions of time \\( t \\), governed by the differential equations \\(\\dot{x} = Ax\\) and \\(\\dot{y} = By\\), respectively. A Laplace transform is then applied yielding \\( Z(s) = \\mathcal{L}\\{z(t)\\} \\).

If an intervention is applied at time \\( t_1 \\) in the form of a step function \\( u(t-t_1) \\) affecting both \\( x(t) \\) and \\( y(t) \\) equally, will the resulting Laplace transforms \\( X(s) \\) and \\( Y(s) \\) only reflect the natural evolution based on \\( A \\) and \\( B \\) from \\( t=0 \\) to \\( t=t_1 \\)?
Explanation: The intervention with the step function introduces a discontinuity at \\( t_1 \\), affecting the subsequent time evolution of both \\( x(t) \\) and \\( y(t) \\). Therefore, the Laplace transforms \\( X(s) \\) and \\( Y(s) \\) will reflect not only the natural dynamics governed by \\( A \\) and \\( B \\) but also the effects of the intervention from \\( t_1 \\) onward.
